articles.title: Reddit targeted by Australia’s under-16s social media ban as ‘dynamic’ list of online services grows
articles.trailText: Popular platform added to list of companies required to restrict access for children, along with video streaming site Kick
articles.summary: Australia’s social media ban for under-16s, effective Dec 10, now includes Reddit and streaming site Kick alongside Facebook, Snapchat, Instagram, X, YouTube and TikTok. The federal eSafety commissioner says this “dynamic list” could expand to platforms like Roblox, Discord, OpenAI’s Sora and Bluesky, with companies expected to self-assess compliance or incur fines up to A$49.5 m. Critics warn late additions risk confusing users, while ministers pledge robust age-verification and monitoring of user migration across services.

articles.title: Tell us: what 90s dance track would you gift to your teenager?
articles.trailText: The John Lewis Christmas ad boy buys his dad a vinyl copy of the house track Where Love Lives by Alison Limerick. But what would be your choice?
articles.summary: In its new Christmas ad, John Lewis shows a boy buying his dad a vinyl of Alison Limerick’s 1990 house hit “Where Love Lives.” The retailer then asks readers to share the 90s club or dance track they’d gift to a teenager today, inviting personal stories and photos through an on-page submission form. Participants are prompted to check the site’s terms of service and privacy policy before sending entries, with a troubleshooting link for form issues. The initiative seeks to combine nostalgia and intergenerational connection by crowdsourcing iconic 90s anthems.

articles.title: BBC’s Kingdom series gets viewers ‘into the action’ with TV drama techniques
articles.trailText: New David Attenborough show’s use of drones and moving cameras creates immersive experience like Adolescence
articles.summary: BBC’s new six-part natural history series Kingdom uses TV-drama techniques—moving cameras, silent “flying cinematographer” drones and cliffhanger endings—to immerse viewers on a Zambian riverbank. Over five years, the BBC Studios NHU tracked lions, leopards, wild dogs and hyenas, revealing how the arrival of a wild-dog pack shifts each species’ fortunes. Innovations include light-sensitive cameras for extra shooting hours, a solar-powered base camp and character-driven storylines (notably Flint, a three-legged hound). Narrated by David Attenborough, Kingdom aims to set a new gold standard in immersive wildlife filmmaking.

articles.title: John Lewis ad kickstarts Christmas countdown to the tune of 90s club classic
articles.trailText: Department store chain banks on nostalgia to get customers into festive mood with Where Love Lives
articles.summary: John Lewis kicks off Christmas on Nov 4 with its 2025 advert set to Alison Limerick’s 1990s club hit “Where Love Lives,” reimagined by Labrinth. Created by Saatchi & Saatchi, the film forgoes cute characters to show a middle-aged dad transported back to the dancefloor when his teenage son gifts him a vinyl record. Launching 10 days earlier than last year alongside an online shop open since August, a £14.99 limited-edition record will raise funds for the partnership’s Building Happier Futures care programme. Amid rising festive ad spend and rivals’ early campaigns, the spot underscores nostalgia, family bonds and shifting retail marketing trends.

articles.title: David Gow, former Guardian Germany correspondent, dies aged 80
articles.trailText: ‘Impressively professional journalist’ with a commitment to social justice was also European business editor
articles.summary: David Gow, 80, a former Guardian Germany correspondent and European business editor, has died of a heart attack. An Oxford‐educated linguist fluent in French and German, he began at the Scotsman in 1969 and covered German reunification in Bonn before returning to London and then Brussels as business correspondent until retiring in 2012. A lifelong pro-EU campaigner and social justice advocate, he contributed to Social Europe, the Jacques Delors Centre and EMiS, served on the NUJ executive, and was elected a Royal Society of Edinburgh fellow in 2023. He is survived by his wife Gayle, daughter Gemma, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

articles.title: BBC accused of selectively editing Trump clip from day of Capitol attack
articles.trailText: Panorama spliced together clips to make it appear clearer president encouraged attack, former external adviser says
articles.summary: Former BBC adviser Michael Prescott accused Panorama of splicing two January 6, 2021 Trump speech segments—nearly an hour apart—to imply he urged supporters to walk to the Capitol and fight "like hell," omitting his call for peaceful protest. Prescott's dossier flagged misleading footage and pre-speech march clips, claiming he circulated it in despair at BBC inaction. The BBC says it reviews all feedback. The dispute risks further straining BBC-White House relations after past accusations.

articles.title: Telegraph bidder reported for potential breach of editorial independence rules
articles.trailText: UK government alerted after RedBird Capital’s boss allegedly threatened to ‘go to war’ with the title’s newsroom
articles.summary: RedBird Capital CEO Gerry Cardinale, bidder for the Daily Telegraph, has been reported to the DCMS by independent TMG directors for allegedly threatening to “go to war” with the newsroom and replace editor Chris Evans—potentially breaching 2024 statutory editorial-independence rules that protect key staff and require government notification. The sale, after the Barclays ceded control to RedBird IMI (backed by Abu Dhabi’s IMI), was revived when a 2025 law permitted up to 15% foreign stakes. RedBird pledges an independent advisory board under Lord Black to safeguard journalistic integrity.

articles.title: David Gow obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist, gifted linguist and European business editor of the Guardian who was dismayed by Brexit
articles.summary: Guardian journalist David Gow (1945–2025) served as education editor, Germany correspondent and European business editor, covering the Cold War’s end, 9/11 and EU affairs. A graduate of Oxford in French and German, his fluency and Europhile convictions made him a leading commentator who decried Brexit. Beginning at the Scotsman and Thames TV, he later reported from Brussels and Wall Street. Post-retirement he advised EU think tanks, co-founded the Sceptical Scot forum and blogged on community issues. He is survived by wife Gayle, daughter Gemma, three grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and brother Rod.

articles.title: TalkTV breached impartiality rules with allegations about cancelled local elections, Ofcom finds
articles.trailText: Claim that elections were cancelled because ministers were ‘terrified of Reform’ given rare rebuke by regulator
articles.summary: Ofcom finds TalkTV breached due impartiality rules after host Kevin O’Sullivan and Isabel Oakeshott repeatedly claimed ministers cancelled 13 local elections out of fear of Reform UK’s Nigel Farage, describing government warnings on boundary changes as “old drivel.” The rare regulatory ruling criticized absence of the government viewpoint. Ministers had explained postponements as cost-saving amid local authority reorganizations. News UK acknowledged the lapse, noting Talk’s provocative tone. Launched in 2022 and online-only since 2024, TalkTV trails GB News in growth.

articles.title: Richard Gott obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist, historian and author who served as a foreign correspondent and features editor of the Guardian
articles.summary: Richard Gott, 87, Guardian journalist and historian, witnessed the CIA-monitored display of Che Guevara’s body in Bolivia in 1967. A leader writer on European affairs and features editor (1978–89) then literary editor (1992–94), he authored seminal works on Latin America including Cuba: A New History (2004), Guerrilla Movements in Latin America (1970) and Britain’s Empire (2011). His career suffered a blow in 1994 when he admitted accepting Soviet-paid trips and expenses. Married twice, father of two, he remained a passionate critic of imperialism and settler colonialism, survived by second wife Vivien, children Inti and Araucana and six grandchildren.

articles.title: Richard Gott, former Guardian journalist and historian, dies aged 87
articles.trailText: Charismatic figure of the left is remembered as one of the most informed commentators on Latin American affairs
articles.summary: Richard Gott, who died aged 87, was a Guardian journalist from 1964 to 1994 and later contributor, serving as foreign correspondent, leader writer, features and literary editor. A leading expert on Latin America, he met Che Guevara in 1963 and identified his body in Bolivia in 1967. In 1994 he resigned amid KGB informer allegations which he denied though he admitted accepting Soviet-funded trips. He launched the Guardian’s influential Agenda page, stood for the Radical Alliance in 1966, and authored acclaimed works on appeasement and Cuba. He co-authored the bestselling 'The Appeasers' early in his career and in 2004 published the authoritative 'Cuba: A New History'.

articles.title: Who will Bari Weiss pick as the next anchor of CBS Evening News?
articles.trailText: With John Dickerson heading out and show’s ratings struggling, new CBS editor-in-chief is looking at several anchors at rival networks
articles.summary: Bari Weiss, CBS News’s new editor-in-chief, must replace departing co-anchor John Dickerson and revive the struggling CBS Evening News. Management, including president Tom Cibrowski, will likely shift back to a single-anchor format, weighing internal candidates like Tony Dokoupil or Norah O’Donnell against external anchors Bret Baier, Anderson Cooper and Dana Perino—all tied to multi-year contracts—and the unlikely Shepard Smith. A January revamp favoring in-depth reports over Washington briefs failed to boost viewership, leaving CBS third (3.7 M) behind ABC’s 7.5 M and NBC’s 5.7 M. Weiss’s choice will signal her broader turnaround strategy.

articles.title: ABC executive who sacked Antoinette Lattouf paid $836,000 for eight-month employment, annual report shows
articles.trailText: Chris Oliver-Taylor’s remuneration exceeded by former managing director David Anderson’s $1.2m package, broadcaster says
articles.summary: ABC’s annual report shows ex-chief content officer Chris Oliver-Taylor earned $836,098 over eight months including a $342,436 payout after his role was downgraded weeks before he was due to testify in Antoinette Lattouf’s legal case. A federal court found he unlawfully terminated Lattouf over her Gaza views, costing the broadcaster $2.5m in defense. Chair Kim Williams and new MD Hugh Marks apologized. Top executive pay included former MD David Anderson on $1.2m. ABC’s funding fell 13.7% in real terms, wages rose to $619m, contractor costs hit $48m, 50 roles cut, and iview users rose to 2.4m weekly.

articles.title: News Corp books in advertisers in campaign for a ‘self-reliant’ Australia that ‘made things here’ | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Daily Telegraph editor says the campaign aligns with the values of its backers, which include RM Williams, Qantas and Bunnings. Plus: Stokes defiant on BRS
articles.summary: News Corp has rolled out a sales-driven “Back Australia” campaign—fronted by Daily Telegraph columnist Joe Hildebrand and supported by brands from RM Williams to Bunnings—urging a return to 1960s manufacturing and national self-reliance, despite its own outlets’ past free-market critiques. Elsewhere, the ABC ombudsman dismissed 108 identical complaints accusing its Gaza coverage of bias; Ita Buttrose’s new memoir notably omits her role in the Lattouf dismissal dispute; and Seven West’s Kerry Stokes, amid a $13.5 m defamation cost order, defends funding Ben Roberts-Smith and insists on newsroom editorial independence.

articles.title: Jean Finlayson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Campaigning journalist who wrote for the Guardian and the Times
articles.summary: Jean Finlayson, US-born journalist and campaigner, died aged 91. Raised in rural Illinois, she won a journalism scholarship at the University of Missouri (1956) and worked on a farming magazine while piloting herself across Texas. After moving to the UK in 1958, she joined CND protests, married Scottish biochemist Vic Finlayson in 1963, and freelanced for the Guardian, Times and Sunday Times. She raised awareness of dyslexia, child custody ‘tug of love’ cases and domestic violence. From 1970–77 she columned for the Bath Evening Chronicle and then edited publications at the Further Education Staff College until 1989. An avid traveller and reader, she faced dementia in later years. Survived by two children and four grandchildren.

articles.title: WPP jobs at risk as ad group’s new boss condemns ‘unacceptable’ performance
articles.trailText: Review launched after firm struggles to stem exodus of clients and compete with AI and data capabilities of rivals
articles.summary: WPP’s new CEO Cindy Rose has launched a strategic review after a fresh profit warning, citing “unacceptable” performance as client losses mount and rivals outpace the ad group in AI and data capabilities. The plan aims to simplify operations, expand tech-driven services and boost cost efficiency across its 100,000-strong workforce—where job cuts are now possible. WPP warned 2025 net revenue will fall 5.5–6% and operating margin dip to 13%, triggering a 16% share slide to a 1998 low.

articles.title: Lachlan Murdoch’s top adviser Siobhan McKenna resigns from News Corp
articles.trailText: Company’s Australian broadcast chief, who was involved in negotiations over Murdoch family’s succession plans, to depart media giant
articles.summary: Siobhan McKenna, News Corp’s Australian broadcasting chief and Lachlan Murdoch’s top adviser, will resign at year-end after the April sale of Foxtel Group to DAZN shrank her pay TV and streaming portfolio. A former McKinsey partner, she steered Murdoch through the Nevada family trust case that awarded his three older siblings $1.1 bn each, co-founded Illyria with him, and transformed Nova, Ten, Sky News Australia and Foxtel into digital successes. CEO Robert Thomson praised her “visionary” leadership, including her 2022 appointment as Australia Post chair.

articles.title: Telegraph sale in turmoil after lead bidder linked to China’s politburo
articles.trailText: Media group’s own paper publishes photograph of RedBird Capital chair with alleged spy ring chief
articles.summary: Telegraph Media Group’s proposed sale to RedBird Capital has sparked fresh controversy after the Daily Telegraph published a photo of RedBird chair John Thornton shaking hands with Cai Qi, a top Chinese Communist Party politburo member and alleged spy ring ringleader. MPs including Iain Duncan Smith demand a formal probe under media freedom laws amid fears of undue Chinese influence. RedBird’s bid follows a 2024 law allowing foreign ownership up to 15%, with funding partly from Abu Dhabi’s IMI. Critics warn the deal masks attempts to buy UK media clout.

articles.title: CBS News staffers lose jobs in ‘bloodbath’ as part of sweeping cuts from Paramount
articles.trailText: Paramount laying off about 1,000 staffers, including some in news, on Wednesday amid longer-term cost-cutting plan
articles.summary: Paramount began Wednesday a wave of cost cuts tied to its $2bn Skydance merger, laying off ~1,000 staff company-wide, including under-100 at CBS News. Described as a “bloodbath,” CBS closed its Johannesburg bureau, axed CBS Mornings Plus and Evening News Plus streams, gutted its race and culture unit, and will revamp its Saturday show. Editor-in-chief Bari Weiss addressed staff, while CBS anchor John Dickerson and standards chief Claudia Milne recently announced departures amid the shakeup.

articles.title: Peter Frost obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Columnist on the Morning Star newspaper who also wrote for many years on camping and caravanning
articles.summary: Peter Frost, who died aged 79, was best known for his weekly Frosty’s Ramblings column in the Morning Star (2012–22), a blend of wildlife, working-class history and pointed politics that attracted readers such as Jeremy Corbyn. Born in Harlesden, he left school at 16, joined the Young Communist League, edited Soviet Weekly’s art pages and led Camping and Caravanning Club magazine until 2006. In retirement he chaired the Caravan Writers’ Guild, authored guides and studies including Comrade Marilyn and Hidden from History, and served on Norfolk’s Broads Authority and heritage trusts. He is survived by his wife Ann, their child, two grandchildren and his sister.

articles.title: ‘Cable Cowboy’ John Malone to step down from his media empire
articles.trailText: Retirement of billionaire, 84, leaves Rupert Murdoch as last of that generation to be actively involved in media business
articles.summary: Billionaire media mogul John Malone, 84, known as the "Cable Cowboy", will step down in January as chair of Liberty Media (owner of Formula One) and Liberty Global (parent of Virgin Media O2). He will become emeritus chair while remaining a controlling shareholder. CEOs Mike Fries and Robert "Dob" Bennett will succeed him. Malone said he will focus on high-level strategy and deal-making, reducing travel and operational duties, though he retains extensive private interests—from ranching to horse racing. His retreat leaves Rupert Murdoch as the only active mogul of that era; Malone's net worth is $10.6bn, and he owns 2.2m US acres.

articles.title: MSNBC hosts criticize owner Comcast for donating to Trump ballroom
articles.trailText: Rachel Maddow said Comcast ‘wants to pay for Trump to take … an excavator to the White House’
articles.summary: MSNBC hosts including Rachel Maddow and Lawrence O’Donnell sharply criticized parent company Comcast for donating to Trump’s $300 million East Wing ballroom project, calling it a self-serving act rife with quid pro quo risks. They highlighted Comcast’s profit motive amid the network’s imminent spin-off into Versant (MS NOW) and warned of reputational and financial fallout. Earlier, Stephanie Ruhle and guest David Frum similarly flagged corporate donors’ expectation of a return on their investment.

articles.title: CBS News anchor John Dickerson becomes latest figure to exit network
articles.trailText: Announcement comes amid concerns about network’s ownership and ability to maintain editorial independence
articles.summary: John Dickerson, a 16-year CBS News veteran and co-anchor of CBS Evening News, announced via Instagram he will resign at year’s end amid concerns over Paramount’s ownership, a controversial settlement with the Trump administration over a 60 Minutes interview, and perceived threats to editorial independence. His departure follows other high-profile exits under new CEO David Ellison and incoming EIC Bari Weiss, who is seeking a replacement—possibly Fox’s Bret Baier—and likely spells the end of CBS’s two-anchor Evening News format. Industry insiders lament the loss of his integrity and journalistic rigor.

articles.title: ‘Unflappable, witty and super smart’: the rise and rise of Claudia Winkleman
articles.trailText: After announcing her Strictly exit, the presenter is said to be in advanced talks about her own chatshow
articles.summary: After announcing her exit from Strictly Come Dancing, Claudia Winkleman is in advanced talks with So Television for a primetime BBC chatshow slot, aiming for a glitzy, Jonathan Ross–esque format to fill Graham Norton’s off-air window. The Cambridge alum and former travel writer turned TV stalwart—known for a low-ego style on Strictly, The Traitors and The Piano, and her distinctive fringe and kohl-lined look—brings cross-generational appeal. Industry insiders praise her wit, calm presence and brand, though warn a chatshow demands a stronger presenter ego. A successful launch would be crucial for her post-Strictly career and BBC’s grip on her talent.

articles.title: Murdoch’s flagship hails ‘terrifyingly funny’ Succession, without a nod to the family who inspired it | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: The Australian names HBO drama the best TV show of the past 25 years. Plus: reporters in the spotlight at the White House
articles.summary: The Australian’s newly launched culture section names HBO’s Succession the best TV show of the past 25 years, praising its ‘terrifyingly funny’ portrayal of corporate dynasty yet omitting the Murdoch family reference. Reporters Geordie Gray, Graeme Blundell et al curated the 25-show list, and the paper released a video featuring staff highlights. In Washington, Latika Bourke described Donald Trump’s ‘you don’t know what you’re talking about’ retort during a Ukraine-war question. Back home, Chris Kenny defended right-wing provocateur Avi Yemini’s harassment of ABC’s Matthew Doran as ‘rough justice’. Meanwhile, former ABC chair Ita Buttrose and ex-Qantas CEO Alan Joyce are set to publish tell-all memoirs.

articles.title: Sopranos creator David Chase to write HBO limited series on CIA drug program
articles.trailText: Return marks his first TV series since groundbreaking mob drama, and will examine covert mind-control program
articles.summary: David Chase, creator of The Sopranos, will write MKUltra, an HBO limited series based on John Lisle’s Project Mind Control book, exploring CIA scientist Sidney Gottlieb’s covert Cold War experiments with LSD, hypnosis and torture on volunteers and coerced subjects from 1953 to 1973. Subjects included CIA volunteers, military officers, students, mental patients, prisoners, addicts and sex workers, some suffering permanent harm. It marks Chase’s first TV series since The Sopranos, after directing Not Fade Away and co-writing the Sopranos prequel Many Saints of Newark. At 78, he criticizes modern TV executives for dumbing down complex dramas.

articles.title: Fox News host Laura Ingraham joins business venture with Donald Trump Jr
articles.trailText: Host often criticized Hunter Biden’s business on her show and said he capitalized on his father’s presidency for deals
articles.summary: Fox News host Laura Ingraham has joined the board of Colombier Acquisition Corp III, a $260m SPAC alongside Donald Trump Jr and Chamath Palihapitiya. The venture, aiming to “fund the next chapter of American Exceptionalism and help Make America Grow Again,” plans an IPO to merge with a private company. Ingraham, who spent 2023–24 repeatedly criticizing Hunter Biden’s business dealings and likening the Biden family to the Corleones, now aligns with the Trump family’s growing ties to Fox—following Lara Trump’s 2021 contributor role.

articles.title: BBC reporters cannot wear Black Lives Matter T-shirts in newsroom, says Tim Davie
articles.trailText: Director general says it is inappropriate for a journalist who may be covering that issue ‘to be campaigning in that way’
articles.summary: At the Cheltenham Literature Festival, BBC Director-General Tim Davie said staff must leave campaigning symbols at the door: journalists cannot wear Black Lives Matter T-shirts or display items like Kamala Harris mugs in the newsroom to maintain impartiality. While affirming the corporation’s firm stance against racism, he stressed that ‘your religion is journalism,’ and that unbiased coverage of political and social issues requires strict neutrality. Davie also highlighted the need for diversity—including socioeconomic backgrounds—and acknowledged the personal and public challenges this policy invites.

articles.title: Fox News employees expressed concerns network was intentionally aiding Trump, legal filings reveal
articles.trailText: Survey responses cited in $2.7bn defamation lawsuit filed against Fox by voting technology company Smartmatic
articles.summary: An internal Fox News trust survey of 1,040 staff Aug–Sep 2020, cited in Smartmatic’s $2.7 billion defamation suit, shows employees fearing the network served as a “propaganda machine” for Trump, peddling conspiracy theories, hateful rhetoric and prioritizing ideology over fact. Conducted by Great Place to Work, the survey nonetheless certified Fox as a top workplace that year. Staff urged new ethical guidelines, more hard-news focus and distancing from hosts like Carlson and Hannity. One staffer said they’d “sold their soul to the devil” and often left in tears. Fox asserts the responses predate contested election coverage. Summary judgment motions are pending; Smartmatic was recently added to an unrelated DOJ bribery indictment.

articles.title: Digested week: Hit or miss? Conker unboxing craze leaves me baffled | Lucy Mangan
articles.trailText: Plus, unpacking the reason for Ikea’s success and why it’s time for the world to consciously uncouple from Gwyneth Paltrow
articles.summary: In her weekly column, Lucy Mangan explores TikTok’s “conker unboxing” craze—paring chestnuts from spiny husks, dubbed “nature’s blind boxes” or “Labubus”—and wonders if such rituals shouldn’t unfold outdoors; celebrates her Brooklyn Nine-Nine TV merch mania; unpacks psychologists’ claim that self-assembly fuels Ikea’s success—advising reverent adherence to its clear, step-by-step diagrams informed by her own flatpack feats; skewers Gwyneth Paltrow’s plan for a “conscious uncoupling” book and Goop; and recounts her nationwide book tour and burgeoning reading list, praising books’ enduring comfort.

articles.title: Yes … er, no: The Australian backflips after signing on to Pete Hegseth’s Pentagon reporting rules | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: News Corp’s broadsheet was one of very few publications to agree to restrict reporting to authorised material before it changed its mind. Plus: a super blooper
articles.summary: The Australian briefly agreed to Pete Hegseth’s new Pentagon press rules—pledging not to seek unauthorised material and to stay with official escorts—before revoking its assent amid outcry. Major outlets including Fox News, Reuters and the AP had already refused the policy as a free-press threat. The column also flags ABC’s I Was Actually There dating errors on Black Saturday and 9/11, an SMH super-tax headline flop, AFR’s $85k Boris Johnson fee, an ABC podcast ad probe and casual-to-permanent hires at the broadcaster.

articles.title: From The Descendants to Gina: Guardian Australia’s nominations for the 70th annual Walkley awards
articles.trailText: Investigations into Australia’s past and present have been recognised in the excellence in journalism awards
articles.summary: Guardian Australia secured four nominations at the 70th Walkley Awards: The Descendants – a multi-part digital series on frontier-era atrocities, nominated in Indigenous affairs and digital innovation, led by Lorena Allam, Sarah Collard & Ella Archibald-Binge with data & interactive work by Nick Evershed & Andy Ball and visuals by Victoria Hart, Tamati Smith, Ellen Smith & Blake Sharp-Wiggins; Fatal Inaction – exposing 57 inmate deaths from known hanging points – by Christopher Knaus & Ariel Bogle; and the Gina: power, privilege and influence podcast by Sarah Martin’s audio team. Picture editor Carly Earl won the Nikon portrait prize; Alyx Gorman’s All Women Want was long-listed for the Walkley Book Award.

articles.title: Another Guardian link to the Keira Knightley film The Woman in Cabin 10 | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Norman and Joe Shrapnel | Proficiency in English | How to Stay Married | Jilly Cooper’s Riders | What next for Venezuela?
articles.summary: Brief letters note that Joe Shrapnel, co-scriptwriter of The Woman in Cabin 10 starring Keira Knightley as a Guardian reporter, is grandson of esteemed journalist Norman Shrapnel. Correspondents question the UK government’s plan to require migrants to reach A-level English proficiency, ask how many current residents qualify, and share anecdotes about receiving or lending secondhand copies of Jilly Cooper’s How to Stay Married and Riders. Finally, they speculate whether Venezuela—after Maria Corina Machado’s Nobel—will face 1,000% tariffs or pivot to tourism.

articles.title: Peter O’Kill obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Journalist who went from local press and Fleet Street to heading up BBC Breakfast News
articles.summary: Peter O’Kill, 79, press and TV journalist, rose from the Baker’s Review, Bury Free Press and Leicester Mercury through Fleet Street titles to become BBC associate editor of Breakfast News. He produced Breakfast Time’s 1983 debut—earning a BAFTA nomination for Brighton bombing coverage—then shaped the Six O’Clock and One O’Clock News, Weekend News & Sport and early-morning weekend bulletins before retiring in 1996. He later lectured at Ravensbourne College and co-founded Media Minds Consultancy. A lifelong Crystal Palace fan and qualified referee, he played in the Crawdads trio, championed Sunningdale community projects and was diagnosed with cerebellar atrophy and PSP. Survived by his wife, sons Dan and Tom, four grandchildren and a great-grandson.

articles.title: GB News viewers more likely to wrongly believe net migration to UK rising, study finds
articles.trailText: Research also finds majority of people are against letting politicians front current affairs programmes
articles.summary: Cardiff University’s YouGov poll of ~2,000 people (5–6 Oct) finds 84% of frequent GB News viewers wrongly believe net migration rose last year (actual figure halved to 431K), compared with 71% of ITV, 62% of BBC and 51% of Channel 4 viewers. The study also shows 51% of the public oppose politicians hosting current affairs (64% excluding undecided), contradicting Ofcom’s “no consensus” focus-group finding. Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy calls for stricter impartiality rules; Ofcom is only consulting minor tweaks. TV/radio trust stands at 49% (BBC top, GB News 18%), but support for regulation falls from 76% among 50–64s to 57% among 18–24s.

articles.title: International journalists urge Israel to allow reporters into Gaza after ceasefire deal
articles.trailText: Foreign Press Association joins long list of global media agencies demanding press freedom in devastated territory
articles.summary: The Foreign Press Association demanded Israel immediately open Gaza to international reporters after the ceasefire, criticising over a year of blocked access. A Supreme Court hearing on the travel ban is due 23 October. Since October 2023, 197 Palestinian journalists—including AP’s Mariam Dagga and Reuters’ Hussam al-Masri—have been killed; CPJ labels 25 targeted strikes ‘murders’. Israel denies deliberate targeting. A UN rapporteur deemed the October 2023 Lebanon strike that killed Reuters’ Issam Abdallah a war crime. Media coalitions from AFP, BBC and AMEJA have pressed for unfettered reporting and the release of American reporter Emily Wilder.

articles.title: ‘It was a binding experience’: TV producers mourn decline of hot 9pm slot
articles.trailText: UK broadcasters used to rely on big audiences at 9pm, but as viewing habits change, figures are falling below the 1m mark
articles.summary: UK broadcasters’ 9pm prime‐time slot has seen average audiences drop below one million for the first time, with ITV’s Madeleine McCann documentary falling under 900,000 on three occasions. Industry figures say this unprecedented decline reflects the shift to catch‐up services and streaming platforms like Netflix, which fragment viewing and render overnight ratings less meaningful. While live events and hit series — Mr Bates vs the Post Office, Gavin & Stacy, Strictly Come Dancing — still draw millions, producers lament the loss of collective TV moments. Executives now prioritise multi‐week consolidated figures and time‐sensitive programming to create national conversations in a fractured media landscape.

articles.title: SBS gets viewer pushback over decision not to join Eurovision boycott if Israel allowed | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Broadcaster’s acting MD says it’s crucial in these ‘troubling times’ to be impartial. Plus: ABC’s John Lyons takes on Trump
articles.summary: Multicultural broadcaster SBS faces backlash after opting not to join a proposed boycott of Eurovision if Israel competes, prompting audience complaints and Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi’s critique at Senate estimates. Acting MD Jane Palfreyman defends impartiality and updated editorial guidance to use “Occupied Palestinian Territories.” Elsewhere, ABC’s Four Corners probes Trump’s alleged presidential profiteering; the National Press Club abruptly cancels Chris Hedges’s speech on Palestine; One Nation’s Malcolm Roberts grills ABC over a 1975 pederast interview; and Michael Rowland is appointed 7.30 national affairs reporter.

articles.title: Britain should raise the digital age of consent | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Where Denmark is going, the UK must follow, says Daniel Kebede of the National Education Union
articles.summary: Daniel Kebede, general secretary of the National Education Union, urges the UK to follow Denmark’s plan to ban social media use for under-15s by raising the digital age of consent from 13 to 16. He cites 70% public support and warns that voracious social media companies inflict harms—from disrupted sleep and shorter attention spans to eroded social skills and exposure to radical views—and leave students arriving at school anxious and exhausted, while executives profit billions. Kebede’s campaign calls for mandatory digital literacy classes in schools and a windfall tax on tech giants to fund mental health services for children and young people.

articles.title: Hack of age verification firm may have exposed 70,000 Discord users’ ID photos
articles.trailText: Names, email addresses and other contact details of users from around the world could also have been taken
articles.summary: Government ID photos for about 70,000 Discord users were potentially exposed when hackers breached a third-party age-verification vendor handling appeals for locked accounts. The attacker may also have accessed names, emails, contact details, IP addresses and support chats, and is seeking ransom. No full credit cards or passwords were taken. The UK Information Commissioner’s Office is investigating. Experts warn that outsourcing age checks under the Online Safety Act doesn’t remove platform responsibility to secure sensitive data. Discord says only limited accounts were affected.

articles.title: Former BBC controller fears for World Service independence amid defence funding push
articles.trailText: Liliane Landor says journalism must not be ‘linked or subordinated to defence’, as BBC explores new funding sources
articles.summary: Former BBC World Service controller Liliane Landor warns that using the UK defence budget to bolster its funding risks subordinating journalism to government security aims. BBC leaders, citing China and Russia’s overseas media spend, are seeking to diversify the Service’s £400m budget beyond the Foreign Office—after ministers asked for plans with a potential £70m shortfall—to counter disinformation. Mary Hockaday affirms editorial independence must remain sacrosanct with robust safeguards, while director Jonathan Munro explores spreading costs across Whitehall. BBC general secretary Tim Davie aims to double audience reach amid rising international tensions.

articles.title: Richard Desmond asks for ‘generosity’ in £1.3bn National Lottery claim
articles.trailText: Payout likely to be funded by taxpayers if media mogul wins case against gambling regulator
articles.summary: Richard Desmond’s Northern & Shell and The New Lottery Company (TNLC) are suing the UK Gambling Commission for up to £1.3bn, alleging manifest errors in the 2022 National Lottery licence auction that unfairly favoured Allwyn by leaking bid feedback and altering contract terms after award. They argue that undisclosed Gazprom ties and a Czech market-manipulation fine linked to Allwyn’s financiers were never investigated. The regulator, calling the claim “hopeless,” defends its robust process. Desmond rejected a £10m settlement, has incurred £17.5m in costs, and warns any payout would draw on good-cause funds or taxpayers. Trial resumes Monday.

articles.title: Lattouf unlawful termination case has cost ABC at least $2.5m, Hugh Marks tells estimates
articles.trailText: Public broadcaster failed to follow its own processes, boss says, and it was ‘not a good reflection on the organisation’
articles.summary: ABC managing director Hugh Marks told Senate estimates the Antoinette Lattouf wrongful dismissal case cost at least $2.5m in external fees, with internal legal costs yet to be finalised, after the broadcaster failed to adhere to its own editorial and employment processes. In June, Justice Rangiah found ABC breached the Fair Work Act and its enterprise agreement, awarding Lattouf $70k compensation, then ordered a $150k pecuniary penalty and criticised former chief content officer Chris Oliver-Taylor for ignoring risk. Marks said ABC offered a $150k settlement but rejected demands for reinstatement and apology, and stressed the episode highlighted organisational lapses amid ABC’s record 80% trust rating.

articles.title: A rightwing late-night show may have bombed – but the funding behind it is no laughing matter
articles.trailText: Conservative donors spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to make a rightwing Stephen Colbert-style talkshow
articles.summary: Conservative donors, led by the secretive Christian nationalist Ziklag group, poured $400k–500k into four pilot episodes of The Talk Show With Eric Metaxas, a rightwing spin on mainstream late-night formats. Promoted under the Seven Mountain Mandate to reclaim culture, the show relied on hack jokes and washed-up guests like Carrot Top and Victoria Jackson but failed to secure distribution. Producers insist it was meant to be nonpartisan humor, yet its funding and target audience underscore a strategic push by Trump-aligned forces to contest liberal late-night influence amid broader GOP efforts to reshape media and entertainment.

articles.title: News Corp Australia chair says social media platforms are ‘true monsters’ and ‘torment our children’
articles.trailText: Michael Miller also says media must unite against second ‘big steal’ by tech companies seeking changes to copyright law to access content for free
articles.summary: At the Melbourne Press Club, News Corp Australia executive chair Michael Miller condemned social media as ‘true monsters’ that fray social cohesion, fuel misinformation and radicalisation, torment children, prey on the elderly and drive self-harm. He urged media outlets to unite against tech platforms’ bid for free content—criticising proposed text-and-data-mining exemptions in copyright law for AI as ‘theft’, despite unsubstantiated data-centre investment claims—and pressed the government to enforce the under-16s ban and hold digital giants to Optus-level accountability.

articles.title: Steve Smith obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Copywriter responsible for memorable adverts for Harp lager, Pepe Jeans and Leyland trucks
articles.summary: Steve Smith (1957–2025), Coventry-born advertising copywriter, died aged 68 of prostate cancer. A Fitzwilliam College English graduate and 1975 boxing triple blue, he shaped iconic late-1980s campaigns: Harp lager’s “Time for a Sharp Exit,” Leyland Roadrunner truck featuring Gilbert Bataille, Milton Keynes ad inspired by Le Ballon Rouge (music by Nyman), and Pepe Jeans’s World’s Apart, set to the Smiths’ “How Soon Is Now?”. After spells at Cogent Elliott, McCann Erickson and Publicis, he pivoted to sitcom scripts and later qualified as a psychotherapist. Survived by wife Pat Sharpe, daughters Amy and Bethany, and granddaughter Bella.

articles.title: Bari Weiss named editor-in-chief of CBS News as Paramount buys Free Press startup
articles.trailText: Commentator to lead storied US news network, five years after acrimonious exit from New York Times
articles.summary: Bari Weiss, ex-New York Times columnist and Free Press co-founder, is named editor-in-chief of CBS News as Paramount Global acquires her Substack-based startup. Weiss, 41, known for her “radical centrist” views and critiques of “cancel culture,” will report to David Ellison following Paramount’s merger with Skydance Media. She oversees flagship programs like 60 Minutes alongside veteran president Tom Cibrowski. The $150m buyout and Weiss’s broadcast inexperience have provoked staff concern about a conservative shift, editorial priorities and big layoffs amid FCC-approved merger dynamics.

articles.title: Bari Weiss’s ascension to top of CBS News highlights the political winds driving US media rightward
articles.trailText: US media giants have bowed before Maga after Trump’s many lawsuits and the Jimmy Kimmel firestorm
articles.summary: Paramount Skydance’s appointment of Bari Weiss as CBS News editor-in-chief and its $150 million acquisition of her Free Press underscore a pronounced rightward shift in US media under MAGA influence. Weiss, a center-right critic of progressive orthodoxy and ardent Zionist, will report directly to CEO David Ellison. Her trajectory—from departing the New York Times in 2020 over alleged ideological constraints to founding a contrarian outlet, to now helming a legacy news brand—parallels corporate media’s strategic deference to Trump-era lawsuits, regulatory pressure and conservative audiences.

articles.title: Who is Bari Weiss, the new editor-in-chief of CBS News?
articles.trailText: Ex-NYT writer who launched ‘anti-woke commentary’ website will report directly to Paramount Skydance head David Ellison
articles.summary: Paramount Skydance has appointed Bari Weiss, the former New York Times opinion columnist and founder of the anti-woke Free Press, as editor-in-chief of CBS News. Reporting to Paramount Skydance head David Ellison, Weiss will shape coverage after her acrimonious 2020 NYT exit over alleged partisan bias and workplace bullying. A veteran of Haaretz, WSJ and the Times, she built Common Sense into Free Press with investor backing, tackling cancel culture and pro-Israel advocacy. The acquisition aligns with Skydance’s FCC-mandated pledge to diversify viewpoints.

articles.title: BBC bosses want defence budget to help pay for the World Service
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Executives at corporation say media monitoring and anti-disinformation are vital to national security
articles.summary: BBC executives are lobbying to classify parts of the £400m World Service—especially media monitoring and anti-disinformation—as defence spending to offset cuts driven by Keir Starmer’s decision to halve the aid budget. They’re in talks with Whitehall to tap the rising defence budget, currently earmarked to hit 2.5% of GDP by 2027, to avoid a £70m-plus shortfall. Government funding currently covers £137m, one-third of costs; the BBC aims to boost this to near £200m and double its global reach to 1bn people. Talks aim to conclude ahead of the November budget and BBC charter renewal.

articles.title: The ‘relentless years’: ABC has shaken off culture of fear created by external pressure, Hugh Marks tells supporters | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Managing director predicts broadcaster will be stronger in 50 years’ time. Plus: Private Media chief upsets business travellers all over the world
articles.summary: At an ABC Friends event in Sydney, MD Hugh Marks said he found a ‘culture of fear’—result of relentless external pressure from a hostile Coalition, News Corp attacks and $1.2bn in funding cuts—and pledged to build a bolder, trust-driven broadcaster focused on value and impact, stronger in 50 years. The article also notes News Corp’s shift from promoting Foxtel’s Binge to Fox’s free service Tubi; the ABC’s Gaza casualty stat misreport that triggered 56 ombudsman breaches; Private Media CEO Will Hayward’s LinkedIn productivity gaffe; and Four Corners EP Matthew Carney’s Timor-Leste honour.

articles.title: Reform UK council in Nottinghamshire ends ban on local journalists
articles.trailText: Shut-out of Nottingham Post and its website reversed after threat of legal action over damaging freedom of expression
articles.summary: Reform UK–controlled Nottinghamshire County Council has lifted its month-long ban on Nottingham Post and Nottinghamshire Live journalists—imposed by leader Mick Barton after critical coverage of party splits—following a legal threat citing breaches of local government regulations and ECHR article 10. The outlet will again attend public events and receive press releases. The ban, partly eased earlier for BBC-funded local democracy reporters, had drawn condemnation from Keir Starmer and local MPs. Editor Natalie Fahy called the reversal a victory for press freedom, though Barton’s interview availability remains unclear.

articles.title: Kyle & Jackie O Show’s repeated ‘vulgar’ and ‘deeply offensive’ content prompts Acma warning to Kiis
articles.trailText: Network’s broadcast licence could be suspended or cancelled by Australian Communications and Media Authority
articles.summary: The Australian Communications and Media Authority has warned ARN’s Kiis network over the Kyle & Jackie O Show’s repeated vulgar and sexually explicit content, citing seven breaches of decency and complaint-handling rules across Sydney’s Kiis 106.5 and Melbourne’s Kiis 101.1—and 12 breaches this year. Investigated segments featured staff urination clips with graphic genital, menstruation and oral-sex commentary, lewd masturbation and pornography discussions, plus racist and misogynistic insults. ACMA chair Nerida O’Loughlin says ARN must rein in presenters or face licence conditions, undertakings or suspension, while ARN highlights recent compliance steps and the show’s 1.6 million weekly listeners.

articles.title: Tech companies consider giving up efforts to combat misinformation online in Australia
articles.trailText: Critics say misinformation is a big problem that social media platforms profit from
articles.summary: Lobby group Digi is reviewing the 2021 voluntary Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation, signed by Meta, Google, Microsoft and originally X, amid industry calls to drop obligations to combat ‘misinformation’ as too subjective and politically divisive. The code currently requires reporting tools and annual transparency reports. Digi’s discussion paper cites split public views and questions definitional consensus. Critics warn platforms profit from engagement-driven falsehoods, with ACMA’s 2024 report noting fewer takedowns despite 74% of adults concerned about online misinformation. Consultation closes 3 November.

articles.title: Nottingham paper takes legal action over Reform council’s ban on reporters
articles.trailText: Publisher says stopping it from talking to Nottinghamshire council’s leader is breach of the right to free expression
articles.summary: The Nottingham Post and rival Nottinghamshire Live, published by Reach Midlands, has launched legal action against Reform UK–led Nottinghamshire County Council for banning its journalists from interviewing council leader Mick Barton and removing them from press mailings. After failed private talks, Reach’s lawyers argue the ban lacks legal basis, breaches local government rules, councillor code of conduct and ECHR Article 10. A partial lift for BBC-funded democracy reporters precedes a council response by Thursday or further steps. Reform leader Nigel Farage was challenged on the ban during US congressional testimony, and local MPs warn it undermines free expression. Critics, including Lib Dems, decry “Trumpian” tactics.

articles.title: Veep creator Armando Iannucci struggling to fund Trump project due to scared buyers
articles.trailText: Iannucci has been trying to start project involving Trump speeches but has been told to expect retribution
articles.summary: Armando Iannucci, creator of Veep, is facing funding challenges for an untitled TV or film project based on Donald Trump’s speeches, as US buyers fear political retribution and legal harassment under a potential second Trump administration. At a Creative UK event he cited warnings of IRS scrutiny and tariff threats, so he’s exploring non-US backers. The project’s format remains undecided. Iannucci, known for The Death of Stalin, underscores free-speech concerns amid Trump’s threats and a Writers Guild warning against censorship. He also recalled Trump’s cease-and-desist letter over last year’s Apprentice drama, which still earned two Oscar nominations, highlighting industry defamation tensions.

articles.title: Freya Leach’s Sky News Australia program axed after airing anti-Islam guest wearing shirt covered in bacon
articles.trailText: Freya Fires Up night show cancelled but presenter to remain as co-host of a different program
articles.summary: Sky News Australia cancelled Freya Leach’s six-week Sunday night show, Freya Fires Up, after far-right guest Ryan Williams aired an anti-Islam tirade on live TV wearing a bacon-covered shirt. Williams, a Scottish nationalist, boasted he had “enough balls to fight Islam” and wore bacon to mock purported beheading threats. Leach, director of youth policy at the Menzies Research Centre, remains co-host of Sky’s The Late Debate four nights weekly. Sky cut the feed, apologised on-air, conducted an internal review but won’t confirm staffing consequences. Far-right figure Tommy Robinson praised Williams as a “hero.”

articles.title: Polly McDonald obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Television production assistant and manager who later turned to giving careers advice to media professionals
articles.summary: Born Fiona McDonald in Lichfield, Polly McDonald, 74, began as a production assistant at Thames Television in the 1970s on live sports, and in the 1980s produced Channel 4 basketball. She became production manager/executive producer at Childsplay on youth series like Streetwise and in the 1990s was managing director at Lenny Henry’s Crucial Enterprises, exec producing Chef, Funky Black Shorts and Neverwhere. In 2000 she became a life coach and career consultant for media clients including Channel 4 and the BBC. Known for her irreverence and loyalty, she is survived by sister Mary, three nieces and a nephew.

articles.title: Kimmel controversy highlights ‘wildly dangerous’ consolidation of TV broadcasting
articles.trailText: Rush to ‘preempt’ Kimmel’s talkshow after FCC chair’s threats comes as broadcasters seek merger approvals
articles.summary: Jimmy Kimmel’s ABC talk show was briefly pulled after FCC chair Brendan Carr threatened affiliate broadcasters with regulatory reprisals over his criticism of Trump. The controversy coincided with an FCC proposal to raise the 39% national ownership cap—benefiting Sinclair, Nexstar and Gray—and Nexstar’s $6.2 billion bid for Tegna, currently illegal under existing limits. ABC halted then resumed production, but Nexstar and Sinclair continue to preempt the show. Media watchdogs warn that such consolidation concentrates power, harms local news and free speech, and requires Congressional oversight. Kimmel returned to mock Carr’s threat.

articles.title: ‘Blood on these walls’: Mudrat tears into ABC’s Gaza coverage during Triple J live set
articles.trailText: Australian hip-hop artist donned a Palestinian keffiyeh and delivered a blistering critique of the broadcaster and its treatment of Antoinette Lattouf
articles.summary: Mudrat, an Australian hip-hop artist, used Triple J’s Bars of Steel to critique the ABC’s Israel-Gaza war coverage and its treatment of Antoinette Lattouf after a federal court found her dismissal unlawful. Donning a Palestinian keffiyeh, he performed a rap blasting the broadcaster—chanting “Israel is committing genocide” and “free Palestine”—invoking a 1990 NWA protest. ABC said it pre-reviewed the track, issued warnings and moderated comments. The video has 100K+ Instagram views and overwhelmingly positive feedback amid high complaint rates on Middle East coverage.

articles.title: Influencers make the AFR Power List for the first time as Coalition left out in the cold | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Inclusion of Abbie Chatfield, Konrad Benjamin and Betoota Advocate annoys veteran Fin Review journo. Plus: Nine looks to offload talkback stations
articles.summary: AFR Magazine’s Power List for the first time includes social media stars Abbie Chatfield, Konrad Benjamin, Jordan van den Lamb and the Betoota Advocate at No 10, provoking ire from veteran editor Phil Coorey, while Coalition leader Sussan Ley is omitted for the first time in 25 years amid panel barbs. Elsewhere, Channel Seven’s Balibo Five cameramen were posthumously honoured by Timor-Leste, comedian Marty Sheargold was found in breach for sexist Matildas comments and rebranded his tour, Nine launched a strategic review of its AM talkback radio assets, and a judge ruled the ABC’s 2022 dismissal of Antoinette Lattouf unlawful, clearing director Ben Latimer.

articles.title: UK’s YouTube and TikTok content creators deserve more rights, say MPs
articles.trailText: Cross-party group to ‘tear down barriers that stifle talent’, from mortgage difficulties to filming permit problems
articles.summary: A new cross-party parliamentary group led by ex-digital ministers Feryal Clark and Ed Vaizey is calling on the UK government to grant YouTube and TikTok creators greater rights and support, highlighting barriers from equipment shortages and filming-permit delays to mortgage rejections despite their £2.2bn contribution to the economy. MPs warn banks still question creators’ earnings. Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy and Ofcom are pressing YouTube—whose $36bn revenue last year and 45% ad cut spark calls for a fairer deal for traditional broadcasters.

articles.title: Australia’s under 16s social media ban could extend to Reddit, Twitch, Roblox and even dating apps
articles.trailText: Lego Play and Steam among the unexpected additions to the list that includes Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, YouTube and X
articles.summary: Australia’s eSafety commissioner, Julie Inman Grant, has asked 17 platforms—from Meta’s Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp to Snap, TikTok, YouTube, X and services like Reddit, Twitch, Roblox, Steam, Lego Play, Pinterest, Discord, Kick, GitHub, HubApp and Match (Tinder/Hinge)—to self-assess whether they must block under-16s from holding accounts from December 10 under new age-restricted social media laws. Pure gaming services are exempt; eSafety will soon clarify which must comply and publish its own view, citing grooming risks on chat-enabled platforms. Meta is also trialling AI-driven age assurance on Instagram for suspected under-18s.

articles.title: ABC ordered to pay Antoinette Lattouf another $150,000 for unlawful termination over Gaza Instagram post
articles.trailText: Dispute began when radio presenter’s on-air shifts were cut short in 2023
articles.summary: The Federal Court has ordered the ABC to pay broadcaster Antoinette Lattouf an additional A$150,000 in penalties for unlawfully terminating her over a pro-Palestinian Human Rights Watch Instagram post. Justice Darryl Rangiah found ABC senior management breached the Fair Work Act and its enterprise agreement, capitulating to pro-Israel lobby pressure without giving Lattouf a chance to defend herself. This follows an earlier A$70,000 compensation order. The court condemned former content chief Chris Oliver-Taylor’s disregard of legal advice and called for strong deterrence against political interference in employment decisions.

articles.title: Sky News Australia staffer helped arrange bacon on guest’s shirt before offensive anti-Islam interview
articles.trailText: UK-based influencer Ryan Williams posts friendly interaction with staffer revealing how much News Corp knew about the content before the segment
articles.summary: UK influencer Ryan Williams, who wore strips of bacon on his bare chest, delivered a racist, Islamophobic rant on Sky News Australia’s Perth studio program Freya Fires Up, declaring he had “enough balls to fight Islam” and calling Muslims terrorists. Newly released footage shows a Sky staffer cheerfully draping bacon on Williams’ shirt during pre-interview prep, contradicting claims of guest background ignorance. Sky News apologised, launched an urgent review of host Freya Leach’s program and vetting processes, and shifted to prerecorded broadcasts while the investigation continues.

articles.title: Sky News Australia admits editorial failure after guest insults Islam while wearing bacon-covered shirt
articles.trailText: Host Freya Leach sat silently while Ryan Williams called Muslims terrorists and explained he ‘wore’ bacon to protect himself from alleged threats of beheading
articles.summary: Sky News Australia has admitted an editorial failure after guest Ryan Williams, on the new Freya Fires Up show, wore a bacon-strewn shirt and launched a live diatribe calling Muslims terrorists and vowing to “inflict maximum damage on Islam.” Host Freya Leach stayed silent, then apologised and Sky cut the feed mid-broadcast. A spokesperson said the footage was not republished and promised a review of vetting procedures. Williams’ segment, praised by far-right figures including Tommy Robinson, has since circulated online. The incident echoes Sky’s 2018 interview with extremist Blair Cottrell. Williams expects a hate speech arrest.

articles.title: From zero to neo-Nazis: what under-16s may see under Australia’s social media ban, simply by not logging in
articles.trailText: Guardian Australia test finds scrolling shortform videos while logged out of YouTube and TikTok quickly leads to gambling, violent and far-right content
articles.summary: In a week-long logged-out experiment on factory-reset iPhones, Guardian Australia found TikTok and YouTube Shorts’ recommendation algorithms quickly shift from random clips to gambling ads, violent incidents, neo-Nazi propaganda and anti-immigration content after a single news report. Australia’s new under-16s social media ban will force Instagram and X to block minors, but YouTube and TikTok don’t require logins to view feeds, creating a loophole that experts warn will let children access harmful, age-inappropriate material.

articles.title: Publisher criticises Reform council’s ‘Trumpian’ boycott of Nottingham Post
articles.trailText: Reach’s chief content officer says issue is part of a national trend that goes wider than the party
articles.summary: Reach’s chief content officer David Higgerson has accused Reform UK’s Nottingham county council of an “increasingly Trumpian” ban on the 150-year-old Nottingham Post and its website, Nottinghamshire Live, blocking them from interviewing council leader Mick Barton and receiving press releases. Higgerson warns this wider trend of hostile media blackouts—seen also in Hillingdon council’s handling of a BBC local democracy reporter and Nation.Cymru’s challenges with Reform MPs—threatens democratic scrutiny. A bid to debate the ban was thwarted at a council meeting. Editor Natalie Fahy says this saga underscores how future Reform governments might sidestep embarrassing media queries.

articles.title: Israel attack on Yemeni newspaper was second deadliest on journalists ever recorded
articles.trailText: Press freedom group says ‘brutal and unjustified attack’ is deadliest since 2009 Maguindanao massacre in Philippines
articles.summary: On Sept 10, Israeli airstrikes struck a Sana’a newspaper complex housing three Houthi-linked outlets, killing 31 journalists and media staff (35 people including a child) and wounding 131—the deadliest attack on media workers since the 2009 Maguindanao massacre, the Committee to Protect Journalists says. Staff were completing the weekly print edition when hit. Israel said it targeted Houthi military PR in retaliation for missile and Red Sea attacks. CPJ warns this follows a pattern since Oct 7, 2023, with Israeli forces killing 247 journalists in Gaza and Lebanon, often labeling them combatants, risking impunity and breaching international law.

articles.title: Joanna Clarke-Jones obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Guardian journalist whose warm, open-hearted qualities led to a parallel career as a therapeutic counsellor
articles.summary: Joanna Clarke-Jones (53) was a Guardian production editor (Public magazine, Society section, Opinion desk) whose 20-year career combined journalism—focusing on the NHS, local government and social justice—and a parallel therapeutic counselling practice born after her 2016 breast cancer treatment. Born in north London, she studied English and politics at Swansea, reported for the Camden New Journal, worked as a reproductive rights press officer and freelanced for Nursing Times. A cellist, pianist and poet with a lifelong passion for politics and the arts, she completed counselling training in 2018. Diagnosed with glioblastoma in 2023, she died surrounded by loved ones, survived by her son Theo and sister Lorna.

articles.title: Foxtel’s star-crossed Hubbl flames out despite multimillion-dollar marketing push | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Ill-conceived set-top box put into ‘maintenance mode’ just over a year after $1m launch party. Plus: ABC critics revel in Trump clash
articles.summary: Weekly Beast media column reports Foxtel has scrapped marketing of its Hubbl set-top box into ‘maintenance mode’ just 18 months after a $1m launch party and $70m marketing outlay. It highlights News Corp’s Daily Telegraph and Herald Sun delay and framing of a pro-Palestinian Jewish Council advertisement, ACMA’s finding that Channel Seven breached broadcasting rules over domestic violence jokes on Step Outside, criticism of ABC’s John Lyons for his Trump question, and a tribute to veteran Timor-Leste correspondent John Martinkus, who died aged 56 after receiving a civilian award for his coverage of East Timor’s independence vote.

articles.title: ‘Court of King Trump’: how media barons are bowing to president to protect key deals
articles.trailText: Suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s TV show over Charlie Kirk comments is latest sign of business coming under pressure from White House
articles.summary: Disney-owned ABC indefinitely suspended Jimmy Kimmel Live! after Kimmel accused Republicans of exploiting Charlie Kirk’s killing, echoing Nexstar and Sinclair’s decision to drop the show while pursuing FCC approval for multibillion-dollar acquisitions (Tegna, Paramount-Skydance) under Trump-appointed chair Brendan Carr. CBS’s Stephen Colbert faced a similar cancellation ahead of the $8.4bn Paramount-Skydance merger. Analysts warn Trump’s FCC wields licensing leverage to enforce a right-wing editorial line, and his lawsuits against the New York Times and pressure on outlets like the Washington Post and WSJ highlight shrinking media plurality.

articles.title: Native public radio braces for ‘devastating and catastrophic’ Trump budget cuts
articles.trailText: Indigenous broadcasters scramble to maintain weather alerts, language programs and local news
articles.summary: In July Trump signed off on rescinding $1.1 billion from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, slashing CPB support for 1,500 stations. Thirty-six tribal radio outlets—among them Koahnic Broadcast Corporation (KNBA) in Alaska—stand to lose over $9.4 million a year; Koahnic alone faces an $825,000 shortfall. Native stations, vital for weather and missing-persons alerts, language programs and local news, now brace for layoffs or closure. Stations have raised emergency funds—KNBA secured $82,000 in four days, Alaska Community Foundation has $3.5 million of a $15 million goal—and partnered on long-term grants. Leaders warn cuts will be “devastating and catastrophic,” threatening essential rural Indigenous services.

articles.title: UK’s public sector broadcasters demand more prominence on YouTube to combat misinformation
articles.trailText: Bosses say independent news needs to be promoted on social platforms that increasing numbers of viewers are turning to
articles.summary: The BBC and fellow PSBs (S4C, STV, Alba) have united to demand regulations compelling platforms like YouTube to grant their impartial public service content greater prominence and fairer revenue shares, warning that algorithm-driven neglect fuels misinformation. Ofcom signals readiness to enforce such rules as broadcasters’ finances suffer with ad revenue migrating to YouTube and TikTok and licence fee payers falling. YouTube is now the UK’s second-most watched service, particularly among Gen Alpha. ITV and Channel 4 chiefs call for binding regulation or equitable commercial deals to protect trusted journalism and the UK’s social fabric.

articles.title: New details of allegations against broadcaster Alan Jones revealed in court documents
articles.trailText: Former 2GB and Sky News Australia presenter pleads not guilty to 27 charges after number of alleged victims drops from 11 to nine
articles.summary: Veteran broadcaster Alan Jones pleaded not guilty to 27 charges of indecent assault and sexual touching spanning 2004–2020 against nine complainants after two victims and 17 charges were dropped. Court documents outline alleged offences—kissing, stroking, rubbing and undressing—at his Sydney home, restaurants in Kiama and Mosman, the Sydney Opera House and public events. His lawyer won an eight-week adjournment over disclosure and leak concerns, with a local court trial now scheduled for 2026, expected to last six weeks to five months. Jones denies all allegations and will contest the downgraded charges before a magistrate.

articles.title: ABC excluded from Trump’s UK press conference as British officials deny any link to clash with Australian journalist
articles.trailText: Australia’s national broadcaster told by Downing Street that accreditation cancelled for ‘logistical reasons’ as other international outlets also denied entry
articles.summary: Australia’s ABC was barred from Trump’s UK press conference at Chequers, moved to an overflow room for 'logistical reasons' after Downing Street and the UK Foreign Press Association cited capacity constraints, not retaliation for ABC Americas editor John Lyons’s Washington clash. ABC retains accreditation for the Chequers lunch and White House briefings. Lyons, who faced Trump’s ire over questions on his business dealings, is backed by the broadcaster and Australian politicians. UK officials said when the conference was moved indoors, capacity was cut and ten of 15 overseas journalists, including ABC, were reassigned. Downing Street blamed high demand, not politics.
